abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. Lessons that may benefit future operations are
            as follows. Cross conditionalities, and invested decision
            making by an Inter-Ministerial Committee (e.g., appointment
            of project coordinators), are difficult to manage, and can
            create unnecessary problems leading to delays; rather,
            committees at this level, should be involved in the overall
            progress evaluation, strategic directions, and policy
            guidance. And, to ensure effective learning outcomes and
            adequate ownership, project activities should be implemented
            through Ministry structures, further ensuring collaboration
            with end-users in procurement matters, and alignment with
            government recurrent budget applications. Moreover, the
            changing socioeconomic context of a country requires the
            Bank to be responsive to such changes, through a project
            design that would allow government priorities achieve their
            full political support and ownership, and, responsive as
            well to the specialized nature of rehabilitation, through
            adequate consulting engineers' terms of reference, to
            avoid unnecessary addenda during implementation. As for
            capacity building, it is worth noting that such should not
            be limited to staff development, but include as well,
            broader issues of staff retention, and non-salary incentives.
